I have given the advice to extract your businesslogic into pojos and
write =
regular unit-tests for them many times.

I'm currently doing some basic EJB=
 3.0 testing and I found that most
of the issues I had with the previous sp=
ecification are gone. The new
session beans are just pojos with dependency =
injection and the EJB
stuff is merely visible as anotations.

So I guess I'=
m saying I don't feel that there is as much benefit of
extracting the busin=
ess-logic of the session beans as pojos anymore
since the session-beans are=
 in effect pojos already (with
annotations). And can be tested with regular=
 unit tests as they are,
so why complicate things?

Of course it's possible=
 that there are issues I have yet to run in to
and that I'm viewing this fr=
om the sunny side but so far so good.

What I would like to do though (I de=
velop in geronimo) is to be able
to start up open-ejb inside some acceptanc=
e-tests. It looked like it
could be done from open-ejbs site but I have not=
 gotten around to that
yet. I still need to deploy to a server sometimes so=
 maybe the added
benefit of in-test containers are marginal or negative.

I=
'm also interested in any issues people may have had with testing EJB
3.0 s=
tuff, it would be nice to know what to watch out for before I'm
in the midd=
le of it :)

Just my 2 cents...

ns as dumb forwarders

 actual business logic

>
>  This is how I do i=
t and it works very well. It enforces a clear
>  separation between applica=
tion logic, which is written as normal
>  object-oriented code, and the J2E=
E technology. That keeps all the
>  awkward design issues of the J2EE frame=
work well outside the
>  application. The classes that refer to the J2EE fr=
amework are just an
>  adapter layer between the transaction management of =
the app container
>  and the objects of the application itself.
>
>  It mea=
ns that you can easily test the application code in plain JUnit
>  (and jMo=
ck).
>
>  You'll need end-to-end tests to ensure that the adapter layer wor=
ks as
>  expected. But you have those already, I expect.
